case_name: Bhaskar Waman Joshi and Trimbak Waman Joshi v. Narayan Rambilas Aggarwal, Sadan Gopal and Murli Dhar

facts.text: Civil Appeal No.16 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.16 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 14, 1952,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated February 14, 1952 of Nagpur High Court in First Appeal No. 10 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 14, 1952, of the former Nagpur High Court, in First Appeal No. 10 of 1945, arising out of the judgment and decree dated September 25, 1944,

facts.text: Nagpur High Court reversed decree of Second Additional District Judge, Amraoti in Civil Suit No. 5-A of 1944 dated September 25, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated September 25, 1944, of the Second Additional District Judge, Amraoti, in Civil Suit No. 11-A of 1943, Tr. Civil Suit No.5A of 1944. B. Agarwal and A. G. Ratnaparkhi, for the appellants.

facts.text: Deed dated September 10, 1931 executed by Shri Narayan Rambilas Aggarwal and his two sons Sadan Gopal and Murli Dhar in favour of Bhaskar Waman Joshi and Trimbak Waman Joshi.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal raises a question as to the true effect of a deed dated September 10, 1931, executed by Shri Narayan Rambilas Aggarwal and his two sons Sadan Gopal and Murli Dhar in favour of two brothers Bhaskar Waman Joshi and Trimbak Waman Joshi.

facts.text: Deed ostensibly conveys absolute title to three properties in Amravati.

anchor.surface_text: The deed ostensibly conveys an absolute title to certain properties described therein. The transferors under the deed contend that the property transferred by the deed was intended to be mortgaged under a deed of conditional sale.

facts.text: Transferors contend transaction was mortgage by conditional sale.

anchor.surface_text: The transferors under the deed contend that the property transferred by the deed was intended to be mortgaged under a deed of conditional sale. The transferees contend that by the deed an absolute conveyance of the property thereby conveyed was intended

facts.text: Transferees contend absolute conveyance with condition of repurchase within 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: The transferees contend that by the deed an absolute conveyance of the property thereby conveyed was intended and that the conveyance was subject to a condition of repurchase to be exercised within a period of five years from the date of the deed.

facts.text: Properties: 1. house in Amravati outside Amba Gate Municipal No. 5/98 valued Rs. 11,500; 2. Chawl Municipal Nos. 6/857,6/858,6/859 valued Rs. 26,000; 3. house in Dhanraj Lane Municipal No. 3/459 valued Rs. 2,000.

anchor.surface_text: The properties in dispute are three in number  1  a house in Amravati outside the Amba Gate bearing Municipal No. 5/98,  2  A Chawl in Amravati bearing old Municipal Nos. 6/857, 6/858 and 6/859, and  3  a house situated in Dhanraj Lane Amravati bearing old Municipal No. 3/459.

facts.text: Transferors indebted to Imperial Bank Rs. 30,000 and to transferees and relations Rs. 9,500, total Rs. 39,500 satisfied by deed.

anchor.surface_text: By the deed the properties were separately valued. The house at Amba Gate was valued at Rs. 11,500, the Chawl was valued at Rs. 26,000 and the house at Dhanraj Lane was valued at Rs. 2,000. At the date of this transaction, the transferors were indebted to the Imperial Bank of India in the sum of Rs. 30,000

facts.text: Possession delivered to transferees by attornment of tenants.

anchor.surface_text: and Rs. 9,500 were due to the transferees and their relations and friends, and to satisfy this liability of Rs. 39,500 the deed was executed. Possession of the property transferred was delivered by calling upon the tenants in occupation to attorn to the transferees.

facts.text: Transferees constructed eight shops in Amba Gate house compound in 1940-1941 and other constructions in Chawl, sold Dhanraj Lane house to Suraj Mal Salig Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The transferees constructed eight shops in the compound of the Amba Gate house in the year 1940-1941 and made certain other constructions in the compound of the Chawl, and they sold the Dhanraj Lane house to one Suraj Mal Salig Ram.

facts.text: Notice served on August 26, 1943 by transferors to Bhaskar Waman Joshi and representatives of Trimbak Waman Joshi to redeem mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: On the August 26, 1943, the transferors served a notice upon Bhaskar Waman Joshi and the representatives in interest of Trimbak Waman Joshi stating that they were willing to redeem the mortgage created by the deed dated September 10, 1931,

facts.text: Reply by transferees denying right to redeem, claiming afterthought due to rise in prices.

anchor.surface_text: and called upon the transferees to render full, true and proper account of the amount claimable under the deed. By their reply Bhaskar Waman Joshi and the representatives of Trimbak Waman Joshi denied that the transferors had any right to redeem the property conveyed by the deed

facts.text: Suit No. 5-A of 1943 filed on September 9, 1943 by three transferors and joint Hindu family members against Bhaskar, representatives of Trimbak, and Suraj Mal for redemption.

anchor.surface_text: and asserted that the claim to treat the sale as a mortgage was an afterthought in view of the abnormal rise in prices which had lately taken place. On September 9, 1943, the three transferors and other members of their joint Hindu family filed suit No. 5-A of 1943

facts.text: Trial court dismissed suit holding absolute conveyance with repurchase period expired.

anchor.surface_text: The court of first instance dismissed the suit holding that the transaction in the deed dated September 10, 1931, was of the nature of an absolute conveyance with a condition of repurchase and the period limited by the deed for reconveyance had expired long before the date of the suit.

facts.text: High Court held mortgage by conditional sale, reversed and directed redemption decree.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the transaction was a mortgage by conditional sale and on that view reversed the decree and directed that a redemption decree be passed.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered November 3, 1959 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: S. Barlingay, S. N. Andley and Rameshwar Nath, for respondents Nos. 2-7. 1959. November 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-This is an appeal against the decree of the High Court

facts.text: Deed recites Rs. 2,320 due to transferees set off, balance Rs. 37,180 paid by cheques on Imperial Bank.

anchor.surface_text: Ex. D-1 which is the deed in question recites that the transferors were indebted, that they needed Rs. 39,500 to discharge their liability, that Rs. 2,320 were due to the transferees and that amount was set off and the balance of Rs. 37,180 was paid by eight cheques drawn on the Imperial Bank of India.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds transaction was mortgage by conditional sale.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right in holding that the real transaction incorporated in Ex. D-1 was a mortgage and not a sale.

facts.text: Agreement Ex. D-3 executed same day as deed, requesting delay in registration, agreeing to pay 9% interest till reconveyance.

anchor.surface_text: On the date on which the deed was executed, also an agreement Ex. D-3 was executed by the three transferors. That agreement recited that the sale deed was to be executed for past debts and for paying off the debts cheques were taken from the transferees and the transferees were put in possession of the houses sold.

facts.text: Draft sale deed Ex. P-13 included only two properties valued Rs. 10,000 and Rs. 25,000.

anchor.surface_text: Before the execution of the deed Ex. D-1 a draft sale deed was prepared. By the draft sale deed Ex. P-13, only two properties, the Amba Gate house valued at Rs. 10,000 and the Chawl valued at Rs. 25,000 were to be conveyed.

facts.text: Monthly rent from properties Rs. 270.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the transferees contended that the monthly rent received from the tenants occupying the properties was Rs. 270 and deducting therefrom Rs. 48 for municipal taxes

facts.text: Dhanraj Lane house sold to Suraj Mal Salig Ram, defendant in suit.

anchor.surface_text: and they sold the Dhanraj Lane house to one Suraj Mal Salig Ram. On the August 26, 1943, the transferors served a notice upon Bhaskar Waman Joshi

facts.text: Trial court held consideration not inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: The court of first instance held that the consideration for the properties was not inadequate but in the view of the High Court the consideration was wholly inadequate.

facts.text: High Court held consideration wholly inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: but in the view of the High Court the consideration was wholly inadequate.

By cl. c of s. 58 of the Transfer of Property Act,mortgage by conditional sale is defined as follows Where the mortgagor ostensibly sells the mortgaged property- on condition that on default of payment of the mortgage money on a certain date the sale shall become absolute, or on condition that on such payment being made the sale shall become void, or on condition that on such payment being made the buyer shall transfer the property to the seller, the transaction is called a mortgage by conditional sale and the mortgagee, a mortgagee by conditional sale provided that no

concepts.interpretation: Even if the condition is embodied in the sale deed, the transaction is not necessarily a mortgage; it depends on the intention of the parties gathered from the language of the deed and surrounding circumstances. Requires debtor-creditor relationship with price as security on property, distinguishing from absolute sale with repurchase option.

concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of mortgage by conditional sale

anchor.surface_text: provided that no such transaction shall be deemed to be a mortgage unless the condition is embodied in the document which effects or purports to effect the sale. The proviso to this clause was added by Act XX of 1929. Prior to the amendment there was a conflict of decisions on the question whether the condition contained in a separate deed could be taken into account in ascertaining whether a mortgage was intended by the principal deed.

concepts.interpretation: Resolves conflict by requiring condition in the same document as sale; but incorporation alone insufficient without intent to create mortgage.

concepts.unlisted_label: Proviso to Section 58(c), Transfer of Property Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Condition must be in sale document for transaction to be mortgage

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to this clause was added by Act XX of 1929.

concepts.interpretation: Amended TPA s.58(c) to require conditions in the sale deed itself.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: to be exercised by the transferees. Granting that the option of reconveying -the properties against the price mentioned in the deed was to be exercise

concepts.unlisted_description: Amendment to Transfer of Property Act adding proviso to s.58(c)

anchor.surface_text: The question whether by the incorporation of such a condition a transaction ostensibly of sale may be regarded as a mortgage is one of intention of the parties to be gathered from the language of the deed interpreted in the light of the surrounding circumstances.

concepts.unlisted_label: Intention of Parties in Deed Interpretation
concepts.unlisted_description: True nature determined from deed language and surrounding circumstances despite ostensible form

anchor.surface_text: The definition of a mortgage by conditional sale postulates the creation by the transfer of a relation of mortgagor and mortgagee, the price being charged on the property conveyed. In a sale coupled with an agreement to reconvey there is no relation of debtor and creditor nor is the price charged upon the property conveyed, but the sale is subject to an obligation to retransfer the property within the period specified.

concepts.interpretation: Distinguishing test: mortgage requires debtor-creditor tie and security interest; absent in pure sale with repurchase contract.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: pon the property, By calling upon the tenants to attorn to the transferees, possession of the property transferred was delivered and pursuant to the t

concepts.unlisted_description: Key distinguisher between mortgage by conditional sale and sale with right of repurchase

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Narasingerji Gyanagerji v. Panuganti Parthasarathi and Others, the circumstance that the transaction as phrased in the document is ostensibly a sale with a right of repurchase in the vendor, the appearance being laboriously maintained by the words of conveyance needlessly reiterating the description of an absolute interest or the right of repurchase bearing the appearance of a right in relation to the exercise of which time was of the essence is not decisive.

concepts.interpretation: Ostensible form and time essence clause not decisive of sale vs mortgage.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: aft sale deed Ex. P-13, only two properties, the

concepts.unlisted_description: Real character from provisions and circumstances, not mere form or time essence

anchor.surface_text: If the words are plain and unambiguous they must in the light of the evidence of surrounding circumstances be given their true legal effect. If there is ambiguity in the language employed, the intention may be ascertained from the contents of the deed with such extrinsic evidence as may by law be permitted to be adduced to show in what manner the language of the deed was related to existing facts. Oral evidence of intention is not admissible in interpreting the covenants of the deed but evidence to explain or even to contradict the recitals as distinguished from the terms of the documents may of course be given. Evidence of contemporaneous conduct is always admissible as a surrounding circumstance but evidence as to subsequent conduct of the parties is inadmissible.

concepts.interpretation: Permits surrounding circumstances, extrinsic evidence for ambiguity/recitals, contemporaneous conduct; bars oral intention evidence and subsequent conduct.

concepts.interpretation: Agreement Ex. D-3 is mere personal covenant for interest payment, not affecting immovable property rights; admissible without registration.

holdings.text: The real transaction incorporated in Ex. D-1 was a mortgage by conditional sale and not an absolute sale with condition of repurchase.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right in holding that the real transaction incorporated in Ex. D-1 was a mortgage and not a sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention of parties determined from deed language interpreted with surrounding circumstances: debtor-creditor relationship evidenced by financial distress, inadequacy of consideration, contemporaneous Ex. D-3 obliging interest payment till reconveyance, deed covenants placing reconveyance risk on transferors indicating security, applying s.58(c) TPA proviso, Narasingerji precedent rejecting form over substance.

holdings.text: Incorporation of repurchase condition in sale deed under s.58(c) proviso TPA does not necessitate mortgage; requires intent to create mortgagor-mortgagee relation.

anchor.surface_text: But it does not follow that if the condition is incorporated in the deed effecting or purporting to effect a sale a mortgage transaction must of necessity have been intended. The question whether by the incorporation of such a condition a transaction ostensibly of sale may be regarded as a mortgage is one of intention of the parties to be gathered from the language of the deed interpreted in the light of the surrounding circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of 1929 amendment resolving prior conflict on separate deeds but not making incorporation conclusive; intent governs per definition requiring security relation.

holdings.text: True nature of transaction ostensibly sale with repurchase condition is mortgage if creates debtor-creditor relation with price as security on property.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of a mortgage by conditional sale postulates the creation by the transfer of a relation of mortgagor and mortgagee, the price being charged on the property conveyed. In a sale coupled with an agreement to reconvey there is no relation of debtor and creditor nor is the price charged upon the property conveyed, but the sale is subject to an obligation to retransfer the property within the period specified. What distinguishes the two transactions is the relationship of debtor and creditor and the transfer being a security for the debt. The form in which the deed is clothed is not decisive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.58(c) definition distinguishing mortgage (security) from sale+repurchase (no debt charge); form/ostensible sale immaterial.

holdings.text: Ostensible sale form, absolute conveyance words, time essence for repurchase do not decide against mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Narasingerji Gyanagerji v. Panuganti Parthasarathi and Others, the circumstance that the transaction as phrased in the document is ostensibly a sale with a right of repurchase in the vendor, the appearance being laboriously maintained by the words of conveyance needlessly reiterating the description of an absolute interest or the right of repurchase bearing the appearance of a right in relation to the exercise of which time was of the essence is not decisive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council precedent: real character from provisions/circumstances, not labored form or time clause.

holdings.text: In deed interpretation, plain words given effect per surrounding circumstances; ambiguity allows extrinsic evidence on recitals/facts, contemporaneous conduct admissible; oral intention/subsequent conduct inadmissible.

anchor.surface_text: If the words are plain and unambiguous they must in the light of the evidence of surrounding circumstances be given their true legal effect. If there is ambiguity in the language employed, the intention may be ascertained from the contents of the deed with such extrinsic evidence as may by law be permitted to be adduced to show in what manner the language of the deed was related to existing facts. Oral evidence of intention is not admissible in interpreting the covenants of the deed but evidence to explain or even to contradict the recitals as distinguished from the terms of the documents may of course be given. Evidence of contemporaneous conduct is always admissible as a surrounding circumstance but evidence as to subsequent conduct of the parties is inadmissible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard parol evidence rules applied: limits to surrounding facts/contemporaneous acts, excludes post-transaction behavior.

holdings.text: Ex. D-3 agreement admissible in evidence despite non-registration as mere personal covenant to pay interest difference till reconveyance, not affecting immovable property rights.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the transferees urged that this agreement not being registered was inadmissible in evidence. Ex facie the document does not purport to create, declare, limit or extinguish any right, title or interest in immovable property it incorporates a mere personal covenant and it is difficult to appreciate the plea that the document wholly inadmissible for want of registration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17 Registration Act applies only to documents creating/extinguishing property interests; Ex. D-3 personal obligation on interest, evidences intent as contemporaneous.

holdings.text: Ex. D-3 strongly indicates parties regarded deed as mortgage, obliging interest payment on price till reconveyance after accounting rents/expenses.

anchor.surface_text: This agreement and the sale deed were executed on the same day. Evidently by this agreement the transferors undertook to pay the difference between the net rent to be recovered and interest at the rate of nine per cent,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contemporaneous document interpretation: recites sale for debts, requests registration delay, agrees 9% interest shortfall payment till reconveyance per transferee accounts.

holdings.text: Deed covenants (transferees option to force reconveyance, transferors bear all damage risk on repurchase) indicate price charged as security on property.

anchor.surface_text: the covenant that damage to property even on account of circumstances over which the transferees had no control was in the event of reconveyance to be borne by the transferors, is strongly indicative of a mortgage. By this covenant the transferees were invested with the right to call upon the transferors to take back all or any of the houses and to return the price therefor, indicating thereby that the price paid is in truth charged upon the property,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of reconveyance clauses: mutual options, risk allocation to transferors despite no fault, shows security not ownership transfer.

holdings.text: High Court not in error holding consideration inadequate based on rent capitalization, land values from comparable sales exceeding deed prices.

anchor.surface_text: The court of first instance held that the consideration for the properties was not inadequate but in the view of the High Court the consideration was wholly inadequate. ... The High Court is not shown to be in error in accepting the net monthly rental at Rs. 245 per month.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent rent/net calculations (taxes by tenants, flawed deductions); accepts High Court rental Rs.245@5%, land Rs.1-2.4/sqft per sales Ex.P-9/21, artificial Dhanraj valuation; supports mortgage intent.

precedents.citation: Narasingerji Gyanagerji v. Panuganti Parthasarathi and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Narasingerji Gyanagerji v. Panuganti Parthasarathi and Others 1

precedents.case_name: Narasingerji Gyanagerji v. Panuganti Parthasarathi and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: The form of the document as an ostensible sale with right of repurchase where time is of the essence is not decisive of its true nature
precedents.cited_holding: the circumstance that the transaction as phrased in the document is ostensibly a sale with a right of repurchase in the vendor, the appearance being laboriously maintained by the words of conveyance needlessly reiterating the description of an absolute interest or the right of repurchase bearing the appearance of a right in relation to the exercise of which time was of the essence is not decisive

precedents.cited_holding: the description of the document as one of an absolute sale and the right of repurchase bearing the appearance of a right in relation to the exercise of which time is of the essence are not decisive of the true nature of the transaction

anchor.surface_text: But it does not follow that if the condition is incorporated in the deed effecting or purporting to effect a sale a mortgage transaction must of necessity have been intended. The question whether by the incorporation of such a condition a transaction ostensibly of sale may be regarded as a mortgage is one of intention of the parties to be gathered from the language of the deed interpreted in the light of the surrounding circumstances.
In our view, the High Court was right in holding that the real transaction incorporated in Ex. D-1 was a mortgage and not a sale.

General holding on substance of ostensible sale with repurchase condition (debtor-creditor relation) addresses the true effect of the specific deed.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of a mortgage by conditional sale postulates the creation by the transfer of a relation of mortgagor and mortgagee, the price being charged on the property conveyed. In a sale coupled with an agreement to reconvey there is no relation of debtor and creditor nor is the price charged upon the property conveyed, but the sale is subject to an obligation to retransfer the property within the period specified. What distinguishes the two transactions is the relationship of debtor and creditor and the transfer being a security for the debt. The form in which the deed is clothed is not decisive.

edges.explanation: Holding identifies mortgage if debtor-creditor, addressing intent to mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the transferees urged that this agreement not being registered was inadmissible in evidence.
